comments: Equals its own "second derivative" (cf. A006337).Presumably this is the same as the following sequence from Hofstadter's book: the number of triangular numbers between each successive pair of squares. More precisely, a(n) is the number of triangular numbers T such that n^2 <= T < (n+1)^2. E.g. a(3) = 2 because 3^2 <= T < 4^2 permits T(4) = 10 and T(5) = 15 and no other triangular number. - _Hugo van der Sanden_, May 03 2005.a(n) = A214848(n) = A022846(n+1) - A022846(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 03 2014
references: Douglas Hofstadter, "Fluid Concepts and Creative Analogies", Chapter 1: "To seek whence cometh a sequence".
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
D. R. Hofstadter, Eta-Lore [Cached copy, with permission]
D. R. Hofstadter, Pi-Mu Sequences [Cached copy, with permission]

mathematica: a[n_] := Floor[(n+1)*Sqrt[2]+1/2] - Floor[n*Sqrt[2]+1/2]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 105}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Nov 24 2015 *)
prog: (Haskell)a006338 n = a006338_list !! (n-1)a006338_list = tail a214848_list-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 03 2014
author: D. R. Hofstadter, Jul 15 1977
